questions.text: What is the function of Acetone free Methanol in Leishman stain?

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.solution:
Acetone free methanol is used in fixation (preservation of biological tissues from decay which acts by preventing metabolic and enzyme activity and not by fixing the cells to the slide).

Acetone (lipid solvent) is not used as it causes shrinkage and destruction of cell membrane making identification of cells difficult:

Fixation can be achieved by
A. Physical method:

  • Heating
  • Microwaving
  • Cryopreservation

B. Chemical method:

  • Immersion of specimen in fixative
  • Perfusing vascular system with a fixative

The most commonly used fixative is 10% neutral buffered formalin.

Technique/Tissue Fixative
Electron microscopy Glutaral dehyde
Trephine biopsy-bone marrow Zenker's fluid (AZF fixative)
GI biopsies Bouin's fixative
Brain Formalin ammonium chloride
Adrenal biopsy Orth's fluid
PAP smear Ethanol

questions.text: ALK positivity is seen in which of the following neoplasms:
questions.solution:
ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) positivity (translocation) is seen in Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of lung.

ALK positivity means the rearrangements in the ALK gene on chromosome 2p23.

These rearrangements break the ALK locus leads to the formation of chimeric genes encoding signalling pathways.

ALK rearrangements carry a very good prognosis as they show good response to treatment with ALK kinase inhibitors. The tumours lacking ALK rearrangements have a substantially worse prognosis. 

ALK positivity is seen in:

  • Adenocarcinoma of Lung
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of Lung

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages n Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

 Other options:

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

 

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

 

Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

questions.text: In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Type 2 occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins
Direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin is seen in type 1
Type 2 is caused by antibodies that recognise complexes of heparin and platelet factor 5

questions.solution:
Type 2 of HIT is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4

Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types:

  • Type I thrombocytopenia
    • Occurs rapidly after the onset of therapy.
    • It most likely results from a direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin.
    • Resolves spontaneously
  • Type II thrombocytopenia is
    • Less common.
    • It occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins.
    • It often leads to life-threatening venous and arterial thrombosis.
    • It is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4, which is a normal component of platelet granules.
    • Heparin should be discontinued and replaced with other non-heparin anticoagulants.

questions.text: A red infarct is seen in all except:

choices.text: Both arterial and venous obstruction occurs simultaneously

questions.solution:
Red infarct occurs in

  • Dual circulation (Lungs and small intestine)
  • Venous occlusion (ovarian tumor)
  • Tissues previously congested by sluggish venous flow
  • Loose, spongy tissues like lung
  • When flow is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (following angioplasty)

questions.text: True statement about the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image is an agarose gel electrophoresis of DNA extracted from culture cells (Ethidium bromide is the stain used and photographed under ultraviolet illumination).

  • Lane C represents a smear pattern seen in case of necrosis.
  • Lane A represents control.
  • Lane B represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. Step ladder pattern due to enzymatic cleavage of nuclear DNA into nucleosome sized fragments, usually multiples of 180-200 base pairs.

questions.text: A 73 years old patient with a history of chronic congestive cardiac failure and secondary pulmonary hypertension was admitted in the ICU for severe breathlessness and pedal edema. The patient dies on the 2nd day of admission and an autopsy was done. On examination of abdominal viscera the liver was found to be enlarged with the following appearance on the cross-section of the specimen. False about this condition is:

choices.text: The pathology here is cirrhosis of liver
Diagnosis is based on Clinical evaluation

questions.solution:
This is an image of a "nutmeg" liver seen with chronic passive congestion of the liver. Note the dark red congested regions that represent the accumulation of RBC's in centrilobular regions.

Congestive hepatopathy is diffuse venous congestion within the liver that results from right-sided heart failure (usually due to cardiomyopathy, tricuspid regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, cor pulmonale, or constrictive pericarditis).

Pathogenesis:

  • Moderate or severe right-sided heart failure causes raised central venous pressure, which is transmitted to the liver via the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.
  • Chronic congestion leads to atrophy of hepatocytes, distention of sinusoids, and centri zonal fibrosis, which, if severe, progresses to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).
  • The basis for liver cell death is probably sinusoidal thrombosis that propagates to the central veins and branches of the portal vein, causing ischemia.

Clinical Picture:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • However, moderate congestion causes right upper quadrant discomfort (due to stretching of the liver capsule) and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Ascites may result from the transmitted central venous hypertension; infrequently, splenomegaly results.
  • With transmitted central venous hypertension, the hepatojugular reflex is present, unlike in hepatic congestion due to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on Clinical evaluation
  • Congestive hepatopathy is suspected in patients who have right-sided heart failure, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Laboratory test results are modestly abnormal: unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin < 3 mg/dL), elevated (usually < 2- to 3-fold) aminotransferases, and prolonged PT/INR.
  • Ascitic fluid, if present, has a high albumin content (typically > 2.5 g/dL); in contrast, only 10% of patients with cirrhotic ascites have ascitic albumin levels that high.
  • Because the laboratory abnormalities are nonspecific, recognition of congestive hepatopathy is ultimately clinical.

questions.text: Polycystic kidney disease genes chromosomes are:
questions.solution:
APKD:

  • Due to mutation of PKD 1 gene (Chromosome 16) and PKD 2 gene (on chromosome 4)
  • PKD 1 and 2 genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins (and not genes) respectively

Autosomal dominant (adult) polycystic kidney disease is a hereditary disorder characterized by multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys that ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure.

PKD1 gene is located on chromosome 16p13.3

  • It encodes a large (460-kD) integral membrane protein named polycystin-1, which has a large extracellular region, multiple transmembrane domains, and a short cytoplasmic tail.
  • Polycystin-1 is expressed in tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron.
  • It contains domains that are usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions.
  • Mutations in PKD1 account for about 85% of cases.

PKD2 gene, located on chromosome 4q21, accounts for most of the remaining cases of the polycystic disease.

  • Its product, polycystin-2, is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules and in many extrarenal tissues.
  • Polycystin-2 functions as a Ca2+ - permeable cation channel.
  • Overall, the disease is less severe than that associated with PKD1 mutations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a worsening headache for 8 months. A left sub frontal mass is resected. Microscopy is as seen below and tumor cells express progesterone receptors.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a tumor with meningothelial whorls, syncytial cells with indistinct cell membranes and psammoma bodies. Most likely diagnosis is a meningioma.

Meningioma: They are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, chordoid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

questions.text: The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of:
questions.solution:
The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

There is no histologic feature that reliably predicts clinical behavior in phaeochromocytomas.

Numbers of mitoses, confluent tumor necrosis, cellular monotony, and spindle cell morphology - associated with an aggressive behavior and increased risk of metastasis, but are not entirely reliable.

Cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, presence of giant cells, mitotic figures, capsular and vascular invasion seen in benign pheochromocytomas.

The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases. These may involve regional lymph nodes, liver, lung, and bone.

questions.text: Which of the following histologic findings would be most suggestive of Buerger’s disease in a patient?

choices.text: Mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasavasorum

questions.solution:
Luminal thrombosis containing small microabscesses composed of neutrophils is seen in thromboangiitis obliterans or Buerger disease.

Option A: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum has been described in Takayasu arteritis.

Option B: Fragmented neutrophils undergoing apoptosis infiltrating blood vessels termed leukocytoclastic vasculitis are seen in small vessel vasculitis.

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels seen in immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient is found on rectal examination to have a hard, irregular nodule within his prostate. A biopsy of this lesion reveals the presence of crowded small glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged, prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry shows the absence of the outer basal cell layer. From what portion of the prostate did this lesion most likely originate?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, palpation of hard, irregular nodules within the prostate with immunohistochemistry revealing the absence of an outer basal layer is suggestive of carcinoma prostate and most prostatic carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common form of cancer affecting men. It arises in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location. 

The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes. Germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 increase the risk of prostate cancer. Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes. Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.

On palpation, it is gritty, and firm in consistency. Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent. Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.

Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

Grade Group 1 (≤6)

 Only individual discrete well-formed glands

Grade Group 2 (3 + 4)

Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform glands

Grade Group 3 (4 + 3)

 Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands

Grade Group 4 (4+4/3+5/5+3)

Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or predominantly mix of well-formed glands and lack of glands

Grade Group 5 (4+5/5+4/5+5)

 Lack of gland formation (or with necrosis) with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands

The image below shows histopathology of prostatic carcinoma

questions.text: Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are called:
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are Brenner tumors or transitional cell tumors.

Transitional cell tumors are a rare type of ovarian epithelial tumor. They contain neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium and are usually benign. They are often detected incidentally and even when large they do not produce any symptoms.

Microscopy features include fibrous stroma, with sharply demarcated nests of urothelial cells, often with mucinous glands in their center, called Walthard cell rests, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option B- Krukenberg tumor is a bilateral metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site in the gastrointestinal tract. Microscopically, it is characterized by the appearance of mucin-secreting signet-ring cells in the tissue of the ovary.

Option C- Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor that commonly produces masculinization or defeminization. These tumors showed a range of  differentiation:

 - Well-differentiated tumors show tubules composed of Sertoli cells or Leydig cells interspersed with stroma
 - Intermediate forms show immature tubules with large eosinophilic Leydig cell
 - Poorly differentiated show sarcomatous pattern

Option D- Hilus cell tumors or pure Leydig cell tumors are also sex cord-stromal tumors. They are rare and unilateral tumors. Large lipid-laden Leydig cells with distinct borders and characteristic rod-shaped cytoplasmic structures called Reinke crystalloids are present in these tumors. Females with hilus cell tumors usually have features of masculinization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pyrogenic cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-18 is not a pyrogenic cytokine.

Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens.

Exogenous pyrogens - Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls

Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins

In the hypothalamus, the prostaglandins, especially PGE2, stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that reset the temperature set point at a higher level.

INF–α (early cytokine) has role fighting off viral infections.

questions.text: The images below display the gross and microscopic features of a brain tumour in a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross features (cystic tumor) and microscopy (microcystic and fibrillary areas) suggest pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytomas typically occur in children and young adults. It is located in the cerebellum, floor, and walls of the third ventricle, the optic nerves, and cerebral hemispheres. It is often cystic. Tumors are often biphasic, with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. Bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork are seen.

Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings. Necrosis and brisk mitotic activity are uncommon.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On resection, the testicular mass is found to be homogenous, grey-white, and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is true for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histological image is suggestive of seminoma of the testes, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels may be elevated.

"Classic" or "typical" seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any hemorrhage or necrosis, as shown in the image below. 

Microscopically, sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa are seen. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehdrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumor burden.

Therapy depends on the stage of the tumor. Seminoma has the best prognosis. Most cases of seminoma stages I and II can be cured by orchiectomy with or without chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: ɑ-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in yolk sac tumors.

Options C and D: Seminoma cells stain positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin by immunohistochemistry.

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: All the following are examples of non-neoplastic polyps except:
questions.solution:
Adenomatous polyps are examples of neoplastic polyps.

GI Polyps are most common in the colo-rectal region. The most common neoplastic polyps are colonic adenomas, which are precursors to the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Neoplastic polyps may be of 3 types:

  1. Tubular adenoma
  2. Villous adenoma 
  3. Tubulovillous adenoma

The non-neoplastic polyps can be further classified as

  • Hyperplastic polyp - benign epithelial proliferations
  • Inflammatory polyp - occurs following repeated injury and healing of the rectal mucosa and presents with rectal bleeding and mucus discharge
  • Hamartomatous polyp - Juvenile polyps and polyps of Peutz-Jegher Syndrome.

questions.text: A 30 year old female presents with pain in right knee since 2 months which is tender on palpation. Radiographs show a 6 cm mass in distal femoral epiphysis with soap bubble appearance. Microscopy of curetted specimen is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL
Majority seen around the knee joint
Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a giant cell tumor of bone. It arises in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis.

Giant cell tumor of bone

  • Benign, locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s.
  • The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL
  • Arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis.
  • Majority seen arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia)
  • Most are solitary
  • Sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.
  • 40% to 60% recur locally
  • Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are seldom fatal.

 

Note:-

 Remember E mnemonic for GCT-

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Eggshell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: An incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) is discovered on a routine chest film. The lesion is resected and microscopy is as seen below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows epithelial clefts lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium with mature adipose tissue and benign cartilage.

The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hamartoma.

  • Most common benign tumor of the lung, most often with a chondromatous element.
  • A relatively common lesion that is usually discovered as an incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) on a routine chest film.
  • Typically solitary, <4 cm, composed of disordered but mature hyaline cartilage, fibrous tissue, smooth muscle, fat, sometimes with calcification/ossification.
  • Cartilage is the most common connective tissue.
  • The epithelial clefts are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium and probably represent entrapment of respiratory epithelium.
  • Nonfamilial Carney triad: Pulmonary chondroma, gastric stromal tumors, functional extra-adrenal paraganglioma.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urine culture showed growth of E. coli. Flexible cystoscopy revealed yellow-brown soft plaques with a central umbilication. Microscopy of the plaque showed Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive of malakoplakia.

Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system.

It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.  

Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, the following findings are seen:

  • Large, foamy macrophages containing -
    • Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products
    • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calcium deposits in lysosomes
  • Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes

Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia. Based on EPO levels:

  • Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased
  • Secondary polycythemia - increased

Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last resort.

Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. Which investigation will help you in arriving at a diagnosis of chloroma?
questions.solution:
• Chloroma is an extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a solid collection of leukemic cells occurring outside of the bone marrow.
  • The best investigation among the given options would be a peripheral blood smear.
  • But the Investigation of Choice for AML is Flow Cytometry

questions.text: Identify the condition where the cells marked in the image is seen:
questions.solution:
The slide shows Anitschkow cells or caterpillar cells which are pathognomic for RF.

  • During acute rheumatic fever, focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues.
  • Distinctive lesions in the heart - Aschoff bodies, consisting of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF)
  • These Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”)

 

Histology showing Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells in Rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: If a chromosome divides in axis perpendicular to the usual axis of division, it forms:
questions.solution:
Chromosomal structural aberrations :

  • Isochromosome formation results when one arm of a chromosome is lost and the remaining arm is duplicated, resulting in a chromosome consisting of two short arms or of two long arms
  • Caused by centromere misdivision leading to formation of isochromosome , the axis of division being perpendicular to the usual axis of division
  • A ring chromosome is a special form of deletion produced when a break occurs at both ends of a chromosome with the fusion of the damaged ends.
  • Ring chromosomes do not behave normally in meiosis or mitosis and usually result in serious consequences
  • In a translocation, a segment of one chromosome is transferred to another.
  • Inversion refers to a rearrangement that involves two breaks within a single chromosome with reincorporation of the inverted, intervening segment.

Isochromosomes:

questions.text: Which of the following is a mediator of opsonization?
questions.solution:
Opsonisation is mediated by C3b and its inactive iC3b

Complements :

  • The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and membrane receptors that function mainly in host defense against microbes and in pathologic inﬂammatory reactions.
  • The system consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 through C9
  • In the process of complement activation, several cleavage products of complement proteins are elaborated that cause increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, and opsonization.
  • The critical step in complement activation is the proteolysis of the third (and most abundant) component, C3.

Cleavage of C3 can occur by one of three pathways:

  • The classical pathway
  • The alternative pathway
  • The lectin pathway

Functions of complements :

  • C3a, C5a and  to a lesser extent C4a – Anaphylotoxins
  • C5a – Chemotaxis
  • C3b and inactive C3b – Opsonisation
  • C5b-9 – Membrane attack complex

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient came to the OPD with complaints of swelling over the cervical region. On examination, it is found to be painless lymphadenopathy along with the presence of splenomegaly. On HPE examination, the following picture given in the image is seen with the absence of centroblasts. Immunophenotyping shows CD23 negative, CD 19 and CD 20 positive.
Which of the following is false regarding the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical and biopsy picture points to Mantle cell lymphoma, which has its origin from naïve B cells, which are characterised by a lack of somatic hypermutation of the IgH gene (Due to the tumour arising from Naive B Cells).

Mantle cell lymphoma :

  • Tumor cells resemble the normal mantle zone B- cells which surround the germinal centre
  • Seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life
  • Has male predominance
  • Has (11;14) translocation (Option A)
  • IgH locus on – chromosome 14
  • Cyclin D1 locus on – chromosome 11
  • Overexpression of Cyclin D1 is seen (Option B)

Features:

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon – lymphomatoid polyposis (Option D)

Histology :

  • Nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centres to produce a nodular appearance at low power or diffusely efface the node.
  • Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours
  • Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively

Immunophenotyping :

  • CD 5+
  • CD 23 negative
  • CD19 and  CD20 positive
  • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain)
  • The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell

questions.text: All are true about dystrophic calcification except:
questions.solution:
Dystrophic calcification is seen in necrosed tissue.

Dystrophic calcification:

  • It is encountered in areas of necrosis, whether they area of coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive type and in foci of enzymatic necrosis of fat.
  • Calcification is almost always present in the atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves, further hampering their function
  • Calcium salts appear macroscopically as fine, white granules or clumps, often felt as gritty deposits
  • Tuberculous lymph nodes can be affected by this
  • Although dystrophic calcification may simply be a telltale sign of previous cell injury, it is often a cause of organ dysfunction
  • Serum calcium is normal in dystrophic calcification

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, weight loss, and fever. A peripheral blood smear was done, and the findings are shown below. Which among the following will indicate a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (ALL). Among the given options, translocations t(9,22) and t(4;11) are indicators of a poor prognosis in ALL.

questions.text: Following penicillin administration, a 45-year-old male has the pathological abnormality depicted in the laryngoscopy image below. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
• Laryngeal edema seen in the image is due to preformed histamine which is released from mast cells in this form of anaphylaxis, which is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis, in some individuals, can induce a severe reaction that occurs within minutes, leading to symptomatology such as acute asthma, laryngeal edema, diarrhea, urticaria, and shock. Classic examples are penicillin allergy and bee sting allergy.

questions.text: A chronically ill patient is found to have anemia. All the following are true about anemia of chronic disease except:

choices.text: May be seen in association with Hodgkin lymphoma
Interleukin-6 stimulates increase in production of hepcidin in this condition
Low serum ferritin and increased  total iron-binding capacity is seen
Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages is seen

questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease shows high serum ferritin and reduced total iron-binding capacity.

Chronic diseases that produce persistent systemic inflammation can impair red cell production and thus cause anemia of chronic disease. This is due to decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors and impaired iron utilization.

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections- osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders- rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms- breast and lung carcinomas, Hodgkin lymphoma

Many effects of inflammation are related to the abnormalities seen in anemia of chronic disease. Inflammatory mediators, like interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulate the production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin in macrophages. This reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to the bone marrow, where erythroid precursors are developing. In addition, erythroid progenitors cannot proliferate adequately because erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the level of anemia.

Clinical features include mild anemia, with the symptoms of the underlying disease. The red cells may be normocytic and normochromic, or hypochromic and microcytic. Increased storage iron in marrow macrophages, high serum ferritin, and a decreased total iron-binding capacity readily rule out the iron deficiency when the smear shows a microcytic hypochromic picture.

questions.text: All of the following may be seen in the accelerated phase of Chronic myelogenous leukemia except:

choices.text: Increasing splenomegaly or white blood cell count while on therapy

questions.solution:
In the accelerated phase of CML, 10 - 19% blasts are seen in blood or marrow.

  • Chronic phase for 3-4 years
  • 50% have accelerated phase
    • 10 - 19% blasts in blood or marrow
    • persistent platelet count < 100K or > 1000K 
    • increasing splenomegaly or white blood cell count while on therapy
    • marked myelofibrosis
    • additional or clonal cytogenetic abnormalities with lack of response to treatment
  • Blast transformation (phase) at mean 3 years after diagnosis
    • ->20% blasts

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are not seen in phaeochromocytomas

Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by

  1. Infarction and calcification of papillae tips
  2. Calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

Psammoma bodies in Tumors:

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus

Psammoma body: a product of dystrophic calcification or of a biologically active process that aims at limiting the growth and spread of a tumor.

Psammoma bodies, H and E stain.

questions.text: The structure in the myeloblast seen in the slide given below is made of __________
questions.solution:
The slide shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. Auer rods are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes.

Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. 

Auer rods are seen in:

  • acute leukemia (myeloblastic, promyelocytic, monomyelocytic and monocytic)
  • myelodysplastic syndromes (RAEB-2) 
  • chronic myelomonocytic leukemia

Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are known as faggot cells which are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: Most abundant cytosolic protein:
questions.solution:
Collagen is most abundant protein but it is extracellular.

  • Most abundant overall and extracellular protein – Collagen
  • Most abundant intracellular protein – Actin

Actin:

  • Actin microfilaments are 5- to 9-nm diameter fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin), the most abundant cytosolic protein in cells.
  • The G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices with a defined polarity; new globular subunits are added (or lost) at the “positive” end of the strand.
  • In muscle cells, the filamentous protein myosin binds to actin, and moves along it, driven by ATP hydrolysis (the basis of muscle contraction).
  • In non-muscle cells, F-actin assembles via an assortment of actin-binding proteins into well-organized bundles and networks that control cell shape and movement.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow shows which of the following?
questions.solution:
Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum see in neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic “puddles.”

In sepsis or severe inflammatory disorders (Ex: Kawasaki disease), leukocytosis is often accompanied by morphologic changes in the neutrophils, such as toxic granulations, Döhle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin.

Pappenheimer bodies are abnormal basophilic granules of iron found inside red blood cells composed of ferritin aggregates, or mitochondria containing aggregated ferritin.

Heinz bodies are inclusion bodies in red blood cells composed of denatured haemoglobin.

questions.text: What is Dicer?
questions.solution:
• Dicer is an enzyme that cleaves mi RNA and involved in gene silencing
  • Dicer enzyme trims the pre-miRNA to generate mature double-stranded miRNAs of 21 to 30 nucleotides.

questions.text: What are sirtuins?
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. These include proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, and inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen free-radicals.
  • They help adapt to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage and hence sirtuins are thought to increase longevity. 
  • Sirtuins also increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism and maybe target for the treatment of diabetes
  • Caloric restriction also increases sirtuins production

questions.solution:
MHC antigens are absent on erythrocytes.

MHC I is expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets.

questions.text:
Sputum from asthma patient may show :
a) Numerous eosinophils
b) Curschmann’s spirals
c) Charcot –Leyden crystals
questions.solution:
Characteristics finding in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimen of an asthma patient is Curschmann spirals, which may result from extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles. Also present are eosinophils and eosinophil protein galectin-10 forms Charcot Leyden crystals.

Other characteristic histologic findings of asthma, collectively called airway remodelling include:

  • Thickening of airway wall
  • Subbasement membrane fibrosis(due to deposition of collagen I and III)
  • Increased vascularity 
  • An increase in the size of the submucosal glands and number of airway goblet cells.
  • Hypertrophy or hyperplasia of bronchial wall muscle.

Airway remodelling also adds an irreversible component to the obstructive disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms?

choices.text: Migration of smooth muscle into the sac
Absence of intimal elastic lamina in the sac
Deposition of mucoid material in the media
Low-grade inflammation of the vessel wall

questions.solution:
The true statement about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms is the absence of intimal elastic interna in the sac.

Saccular (or berry) aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm, most often occurring in the anterior circulation of the circle of Willis. Rupture of this aneurysm is the most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The following factors are implicated in the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysm:

  • Genetic factors: Increased incidence in first-degree relatives
  • Associated syndromes: Increased incidence in individuals with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, Marfan syndrome, etc
  • Predisposing factors: Increased incidence in cigarette smokers and individuals with hypertension

The aneurysmal sac is made up of thickened hyalinized intima and a covering of adventitia. The absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina in the sac suggests that these aneurysms are developmental anomalies. Atheromatous plaques, calcification, thrombi, or prior hemorrhage may be present within the aneurysm.  

Rupture usually occurs at the apex of the sac. It is often associated with a sudden increase in intracranial pressure, such as when straining during defecation or sexual stimulation. Patients complain of an acute excruciating headache and loss of consciousness. The prognosis worsens with each episode.

questions.text: Ectopic rest of normal tissue is known as __________
questions.solution:
Choristoma is ectopic rest of normal tissue. It is a normally arranged tissue at a different anatomical site.

Abnormally arranged tissue at normal site is hamartoma.

questions.text: The Reid Index is:

choices.text: Ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the bronchial wall
Ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the cartilage

questions.solution:
Reid Index is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the bronchial wall (between the epithelium and the cartilage).

It is normally 0.4 and is increased in chronic bronchitis, usually in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

questions.text: Which is true regarding pernicious anemia?

choices.text: Elevated levels of homocysteine and decreased methylmalonic acid in the serum
Four types of antibodies can be present in the serum
Tapeworms can exacerbate a B12 deficiency state
Folate therapy should be initiated first

questions.solution:
Tapeworms compete with the host for B12 and can induce a deficiency state.

Vit B12 is involved in 2 biochemical reactions:

  1. As a cofactor in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine (for DNA synthesis)
  2. Isomerization of methylmalonyl coenzyme A to succinyl coenzyme A (for normal myelination of neurons)

Folic acid is involved only in 1st reaction, not 2nd one.

In B12 deficiency – Both Homocysteine and Methylmalonic acid are elevated.

In Folate deficiency – Only Homocysteine is elevated, no neurological deficits.

Three types of autoantibodies are present in Pernicious anemia

  • Type I antibody -  blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. 
  • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor – vitamin B12 complex to its ileal receptor.
  • Type III antibodies - recognize and bind to the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump.

B12 deficiency should be excluded first before initiating folate therapy in megaloblastic anemia. Because Hematologic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency anemia also respond to folate therapy. However, folate does not prevent (and may even exacerbate) the neurologic deficits.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about Polycythemia Vera (PCV)?
1. Serum erythropoietin levels are low
2. In about 2% of patients, PCV transforms into ALL
questions.solution:
Since Polycythemia Vera is a form of primary Polycythemia, the erythropoietin levels are very low whereas secondary forms of polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels. The progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling.

In about 2% of patients, PCV transforms to AML whereas transformation to ALL is rarely observed. In fact, the interesting point is, this AML clone often lacks JAK2 mutations.

questions.text: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) differ in all of the following aspects except _________
questions.solution:
PT and aPTT levels are normal in both TTP and HUS.

HUS and TTP:

  • TTP is defined as the pentad of fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, transient neurologic deficits, and renal failure.
  • HUS is also associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia but is distinguished by the absence of neurologic symptoms, the prominence of acute renal failure, and its frequent occurrence in children.
  • In both conditions, intravascular thrombi cause microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and widespread organ dysfunction.
  • In HUS, microthrombi mainly contain fibrin whereas in TTP, these are composed of platelet aggregates, fibrin, and VWF.
  • PT and aPTT are usually normal.

 

Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
  • Deficiency of ADAMTS13
    • Inherited (Schulman-Upshaw syndrome)
    • Acquired (autoantibodies)

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

Typical:

  • Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 infection
  • Endothelial damage by Shiga-like toxin
Atypical:
  • Alternative complement pathway inhibitor deficiencies (complement factor H, membrane cofactor protein (CD46), or factor I)
  • Inherited
  • Acquired (autoantibodies)
Miscellaneous associations
  • Drugs (cyclosporine, chemotherapeutic agents)
  • Radiation, bone marrow transplantation
  • Infections (HIV, pneumococcal sepsis)
  • Conditions associated with autoimmunity (SLE, lymphoid neoplasms)

questions.text: Stain used for copper is ________
questions.solution:
Rhodamine stain is used for staining copper.

Copper deposition in hepatocytes can be demonstrated by special stains:

  • Rhodamine stain for copper
  • Orcein stain for copper-associated protein

Rhodamine stain:

questions.text: The variant of Reed Sternberg cell shown below is seen in which type of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (Popcorn Reed Sternberg cell) along with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm. It is seen in the lymphocyte-predominant type of HL.

Reed Sternberg cell:

  • Hodgkins lymphoma is characterised by the presence of a giant cell called as Reed Sternberg cell (RS cell).
  • It is derived from the germinal center B cell.
  • It has a classic owl eyed appearance due to the presence of symmetric or mirror image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.
  • RS Cells can be present in certain other conditions like infectious mononucleosis, solid tissue tumours and immunoblastic lymphoma.
  • There are several variants to RS cells like: Lacunar variant, Mononuclear variant, Pleomorphic, Lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H)

Classical Reed-Sternberg cell has two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, and  is surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophil.

Lacunar variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within a open space, which is an artifact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: World Blood Donor day is celebrated on ________
questions.solution:
World Blood Donor Day is celebrated on 14th June.

NOTE:

  • The slogan for this year’s campaign is 'Safe Blood For All'.
  • The theme of this year’s campaign is 'blood donation and universal access to safe blood transfusion, as a component of achieving universal health coverage'.
  • The host country for World Blood Donor Day 2019 is Rwanda.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).

3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

Related Pearl: Cytoskeleton

Cytoskeleton

Microfilaments

Intermediate Filaments

Microtubules

Diameter

5-9 nm

8-14 nm

25 nm

Examples

Filamentous (F) actin

Globular (G) actin

Keratin, vimentin, desmin, glial fibrillary acid protein, peripherin, neurofilaments, lamins

Dynamin, Dynein, Kinesin,tubulin

Functions

Play a vital role in various cellular contractile systems,

including muscle contraction and amoeboid movement (lamellopodia)

serve as mechanical stiffeners for microvilli

Help resist mechanical stress

Lamins connect nuclear membrane to cell membrane

Keratin prevents blistering of the skin

Vimentin forms a flexible scaffolding for the cell and help it resist external pressure

Maintain asymmetric cell shapes and coordinate complex cell movements

specifically serving as tracks for transport of secretory vesicles within a cell using molecular motors

serving as the main structural and functional component of cilia and flagella

forming a mitotic spindle during cell division

questions.text: The most common site of arteriovenous malformations in the brain is ________
questions.solution:
The most common site of arteriovenous malformations is the territory of the middle cerebral artery, particularly its posterior branches.

Large arteriovenous malformations occurring in the newborn period can lead to congestive heart failure because of shunt effects, especially if the malformation involves the vein of Galen.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted radiologically. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Wolman disease. It is due to a deficiency of the lysosomal acid lipase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive disease.

It leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides. It presents in the first few weeks of life with:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal distention
  • Steatorrhea
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands

No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: Patients with metachromatic leukodystrophy will have which of the following enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive condition caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase A.

The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. These sulfatides can contribute to white matter injury, demyelination, and gliosis.

Macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm are scattered throughout the white matter. They contain metachromatic material, which can be detected in the urine and peripheral nerves when stained with toluidine blue.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy picture of lysosomes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Electron microscopy showing zebra bodies is suggestive of Niemann–Pick disease.

Zebra bodies are engorged secondary lysosomes that contain membranous cytoplasmic bodies resembling concentric lamellated myelin figures. Similar zebra bodies can also be seen in mucopolysaccharidoses.

questions.text: What is the normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio?
questions.solution:
The normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4 to 1:6. 

Normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio implies that the volume occupied by the cytoplasm is 4 to 6 times greater than the volume occupied by the nucleus.

Abnormal nuclear morphologies that are seen in malignant cells:

  • Nuclei disproportionately large for the cell
  • Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular
  • Chromatin 
    • Coarsely clumped 
    • Hyperchromatic
  • Nucleoli are abnormally large

questions.text: In which of the following structures are lines of Zahn seen?
questions.solution:
Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn. These are formed by pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell-rich layers.

They signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood. Their presence can therefore distinguish antemortem clots from the nonlaminated postmortem clots.

The below histopathological image of a thrombus shows these alternating bands called lines of Zahn.

questions.text: Serum concentrations of which of the following decrease during inflammation?
questions.solution:
During inflammation, there are reduced levels of albumin.

This occurs in order to allow an increase in the liver's capacity to synthesize acute phase reactants. Hence, albumin is called a negative phase reactant.

Negative acute-phase proteins concentration decreases during inflammation. These are:

  • Albumin
  • Transferrin
  • Retinol-binding protein
  • Antithrombin
  • Transcortin
  • Alpha 2-HS glycoprotein
  • Alpha-fetoprotein
  • Thyroxin-binding protein
  • Insulin-like growth factor 1
  • Factor 12

Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation. These include C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. The synthesis of these molecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines. IL-6 stimulates the synthesis of CRP and fibrinogen and IL-1 or TNF for SAA.

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a female patient who presented with a lump in her right breast. Presence of which of the following findings is not associated with an increased risk of cancer?
questions.solution:
Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change.

Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of carcinoma.

Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly higher.

Related Pearl: Epithelial Lesions and Risk of Malignancy

Examples

(RR = 1)
  • Duct ectasia
  • Cysts
  • Apocrine change
  • Mild hyperplasia
  • Adenosis
  • Fibroadenoma without complex features

Proliferative Disease Without Atypia

(RR = 1.5 to 2)
  • Moderate or florid hyperplasia
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Papilloma
  • Complex sclerosing lesion (radial scar)
  • Fibroadenoma with complex features

Proliferative Disease with Atypia

(RR = 4 to 5)
  • Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH)
  • Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH)

Carcinoma in situ

(RR = 8 to 10)
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)
  • Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.solution:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma.

The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:

  • Mitotic index - ≥10 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Tumor cell necrosis - 
    • Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas
    • Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show?

choices.text: Proliferating  parietal and visceral epithelial  cells and WBCs in Bowman space
Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
Proliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangium
Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin deposition

questions.solution:
The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis.

RPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and formation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies (ANA).

Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines in the Bowman space. This triggers:

  • Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells 
  • Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts 
  • Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin

The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

IgA nephropathy

Others: Cryoglobulinemia, Bacterial endocarditis, sepsis, acute pancreatitis/advanced liver disease

Type III (Pauci-Immune)

ANCA-associated

Idiopathic

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescence: No immunoglobulin or complement deposits

 

Image: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (PAS stain) with the crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and leukocytes internal to Bowman capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following infections primarily affects the testis?
questions.solution:
Syphilis and mumps affect the testis primarily and later spread to surrounding structures.

Syphilis can affect both the testis and epididymis, but invariably, the testis is involved first as gummas and diffuse interstitial inflammation.

Mumps most commonly affects school-aged children, but testicular involvement is uncommon in this age. Mumps infection in postpubertal males can lead to acute interstitial orchitis in 20 to 30% of cases.

Gonorrhea and tuberculosis affect the epididymis first, which can later spread to the testis.

questions.text: You are collecting a blood sample to send for prothrombin time in a patient in the ward. Which of the following is true about this investigation?

choices.text: Test must be done within 2 hours of sample collection

questions.solution:
The test for prothrombin time is done within 2 hours.

The differences between PT and aPTT are:

Feature PT aPTT
Coagulation pathway tested Extrinsic and common Intrinsic and common
Normal value 11-13 seconds 25-35 seconds
Sample Platelet-poor plasma Platelet-poor plasma
Activating agent Thomboplastin

Kaolin

Silica

Ellagic acid

 

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text:
A newborn baby develops severe umbilical cord bleeding soon after birth. Lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Bleeding time - normal

Platelet count - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - normal

TT - normal

Urea lysis test - positive
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of factor XIII deficiency. A positive urea lysis test confirms the diagnosis.

Factor XIII is also known as clot-stabilizing factor that converts unstable fibrin clot into a stable clot. Its deficiency typically presents as excessive umbilical cord bleeding in the newborn.

Laboratory findings in this condition are:

  • Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT)
  • Positive urea lysis test - confirmatory test which demonstrates lysis of clot by hyperosmolar urea in affected individuals

The parameters for the given diseases:

Condition PT aPTT BT TT Platelet count Urea lysis test 
Vitamin K deficiency increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Von Willebrand disease normal normal/increased increased normal normal negative
Hemorrhagic disease of newborn increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Factor XIII deficiency normal normal normal normal normal positive

questions.text: Which of the following statements about solitary thyroid nodule is incorrect?

choices.text: They are more common in women
Solitary nodules are more likely to be malignant than are multiple nodules
Nodules in younger patients are less likely to be malignant

questions.solution:
Nodules in younger patients are more likely to be malignant than those in older patients.

The solitary thyroid nodule is a palpably discrete swelling within an otherwise apparently normal thyroid gland. A higher incidence is seen in areas with endemic iodine deficiency. They are more common in women than in men. 

Malignant transformation is more common in:

  • Solitary nodules > Multinodular goiter
  • Solitary nodules in males > females
  • Cold nodules > Hot nodules

However, benign neoplasms are more common than thyroid carcinomas by a ratio of nearly 10:1.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid.

The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion.

Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology.

Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: What is the most common clinical feature of Cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Obesity is the most common clinical feature of Cushing's syndrome.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months. Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolonged QT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy).

It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for defense against fungal infections.

It presents in childhood with the following features:

  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails)
  • Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as -
    • Autoimmune adrenalitis
    • Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
    • Idiopathic hypogonadism
    • Pernicious anemia 

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a combination of the following:

  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes

questions.text: CD 45 is present on which of the following WBCs?
questions.solution:
CD45 is present on all leucocytes and is known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA).

Mature T-Cells have CD3 and CD5.

Mature B-Cells have CD19, CD21 and CD23.

NK cells have CD16 and CD56.
